description:
Plenty of parking and a great trail for a short hike.

I entered on Juanita way, but there are many additional entrances! Plenty of neighborhood parking without any meters. 

The hike had a variety of beautiful foliage and fall trees to transport you away from hustle the city. Also a beautiful view at the top with the commemorative concrete cross. 

I came here by myself & was able to navigate through the park very easily because it's quite small. There's incline, but nothing too strenuous. 

Come for the view, the fresh air, and some much needed nature time!
author: Monica H.

description:
Went there for the sunrise based on a friend's recommendation. As some of the pictures shown, if you are lucky, the sunrise is beyond beautiful. The city is below the fog line and it was just the sun and the view.

However we werent that lucky. Carl the fog got in the way. It was just a regular foggy morning lol And gigantic mosquitoes on the top of the hill, hundreds of them, so big they actually bit me through my pants, so we had to go down a level and wait for the sun.

So yeah. 
Your call.
author: Cara D.

description:
Short hike up to the large-scaled white cross on top. Beautiful views of Twin Peaks, Sutro tower, and the city all in one glance. 

- Visited first time on a weekend afternoon. It was a hot day in SF (T-shirt/ shorts type of weather ~ 73+ F) however, walking up towards the hill, under tall trees, it became chilly. Wearing layers (a light jacket or long sleeve shirt) will do.

- The hills are not steep, but rocky. The rocks are in various shapes and size, which makes the path unpredictable. One of us slipped & fell due to the crushed stones & slippery dirt. It's helpful to have a trekking pole, and wear gripping, hiking shoes. 

- There are plenty of spots to take photos along the hike. But the most beautiful is on the top, where you can get a 180 degree panoramic of the city. 

- The cross is very interesting, esp during sunset the sun streaks shine through. 

- This place is dog-friendly (on leash) and overall a very down-to-earth ambiance. Fun place to visit when strolling around Twin peaks, or diamond heights area.
author: Jess W.

description: Best views of the city, less people, small hike, very clean and beautiful. Got some really nice pictures!
author: Chrystian V.

description:
It's cute! I can't believe it took me so long to visit this park. It's really close to my office and has the distinction of being the highest spot in SF. 

We wanted to explore some short urban hikes in the city and chose Mt. Davidson. I wouldn't really call this a "hike" since it only took us about 20 minutes to walk up to the cross. I would maybe pair this with another peak in the city to make the trip worth it. We walked from here to Golden Gate Park for a picnic lunch afterwards which made it a nice day hike.

Although it's the highest spot in SF, the trees around the cross/memorial block most of the view at the top. It's definitely a quiet and reflective place and not as crowded as other climbs in the city.
author: Semuteh F.

description: This is actually a 5 min hike, so if you're looking for an extremely short hike and wanting to take some cool pics, then this is the hike for you. After you drive up some intense hills, you'll see the entrance to the trail. Plenty of parking in the neighborhood. At the top, you'll see a dead tree and a nice view of SF. There are steps that'll also take you to a huge cross. The cross area is a nice escape from the hustle and bustle of the city because it's surrounded by trees. I saw people bringing their dogs and babies up here, so definitely a family friendly hike.
author: Annie S.

description: Loved my first "hike" on Mount Davidson. Really accessible and easy to do with a toddler and infant in an ergo. Not strenuous, but fantastic views of the city in many directions (no Golden Gate Bridge, though). I have no idea how it took me so long to get here... Half hour drive from mid-peninsula well worth it for an easy trek with multi-million dollar views. This is now a new go-to spot to bring out oft owners who don't want anything too strenuous.
author: Jarrad W.

description:
Definitely an SF hike you want to try! Be forewarned, this is a very steep hill hike. Get ready for leg day. There are multiple entrances/trails to go from to get to the top. The main hike trail entrance that I found from multiple websites, started off on Juanita Way. However, through this way the trail was blocked by a fallen tree probably from the previous storms NorCal has been having. I was able to climb over it to get to the trail but it was definitely risky. If you take go up the road instead of taking this trail, it isn't really considered a hike. I do suggest trying the main hike trail. When it isn't foggy you get a beautiful view of the city! If you're looking for a Golden Gate Bridge view, just know this isn't the place that will get you that view :( Overall, I loved the hike! 



Beware of those pesky mosquitos!!!!!!!!!
author: Kimberly D.

description:
the view here is super awesome. dog friendly! I brought my dogs to this park on sunday at around 8am. the parking is easy for me. i don't find parking lot but there are plenty spaces nearby. 
bad thing about this park is that it doesn't have sign about where each trail takes you to. I have to follow my google map trying to figure where i am... and which way to go. But anyway, still enjoy this park. easy trail with amazing view.
author: Tina H.

description:
Surprisingly Mount Davidson is less of a mountain and more of a hill in a quaint little neighborhood. From the side view (refer to photos), it's actually pretty funny to see this fallen tree that looks very underwhelming and rather anti-climatic. However, there's something about standing in the right spot that you get these amazing views that make this random branch look a little magical. 

We parked in the neighborhood and it was a short slightly inclined walk that took maybe 3 minutes tops. Judging from all the photos I've seen of people sitting on this branch, I expected it to be, you know, climbable. Oh geez, it was not. Not at all. I'm actually really confused how many people climb this. It's so tall! I can't even. Anyway, we made it in time for the sunset, mixed wit Karl the fog, and it made for a really dreamy view.
author: Maleah M.

description: The tall cross on top of Mount Davidson is so spiritual, esp when it's Easter Sunday.  You can see the Bay Area  on a clear day.  I may have driven up the crooked and narrow streets, as well as walk up the rocky hill, but seeing the Holy Cross is worth it.
author: Angela W.

description:
Such a beautiful walk.  Up hill, but worth every huff and puff
My dog lived it too
The cross is also amazing
On a clear day, you can see forever
author: Kerrilynn S.

description:
Another hidden gem in SF that I recently just discovered. I love this city!

Views you can see from here are the Sutro Tower, Twin Peaks, and the entire eastern half of San Francisco. Honestly I think views on Grand View Park or Twin Peaks have nicer panoramic views of the city, but I loved it here too just because it has the tree and it'll be a nice Instagram picture, hahaha.
author: Danny L.

description: Mount Davidson Park has such amazing views of San Francisco! It's such a hidden gem that no one knows about. There's multiple entrances, my boyfriend and I went through the entrance on the neighborhood. The entrance is a stairway IN BETWEEN the houses, it's hard to see but just look out for the stairs! The hike is very easy and there's so many alternative routes which make it fun! There's the cross you'll see as you keep hiking! The hike has a lot of trees and brushes. It's nice to see nature in the city.
author: Katty X.

description: Beautiful hike with spectacular views at the top. We have done many hikes in San Francisco and we are so happy to add this one to our list of completed hikes.
author: Pamela S.

description:
This park would have to be another great spot to capture the beautiful views of San Francisco. 
I would consider this area to be a nice "walk" rather than a "hike". 
The trail is a little bit rocky so be careful of that, however, it is worth the walk. I would say the walk is worth 15-30 mins MAX lol.
author: Stacey M.

description: Beautiful hike last weekend. Peaceful and not too crowded. Gorgeous views of the city and lots of picnic spots :) Beautiful smell from trees and flowers!
author: Heliana M.

description:
Easy, short hike up for an awesome view of San Francisco, from the highest point in the city. If you follow Yelp's directions, it will lead you to one of the entrances of the park. There is plenty of parking around the entrances. Don't be discouraged by the narrow path, you will know you are on the right path when you see the SF Recreations sign a couple steps in. I believe it is 1 mile round-trip hike. The first half of the way up is a bit steep, but not bad at all. For reference, my 60 year old mother in decent shape was able to reach the top, being only a bit out of breath. 

At a crossroad, you will see one flatter path, and another path with stairs. For a challenge, go up the stairs. There will be a bit of an incline on a dirt path after that, so make sure to wear shoes with good traction if you opt for that route. Both times, I've gone with the flatter path, which loops around to the top. Make sure to go on a clear day! You won't see much at all otherwise. Check out the huge cross at one end, and walk down to the large tree on the other. You'll be able to see the people on Twin Peaks, granted they will look like ants. Enjoy this hidden gem with the gorgeous view. Just be careful of slipping if you visit right after the rain, since it is all soil.
author: Kristi T.

description: Beautiful , peaceful amazing view good little hike very beautiful you have to find the cross you have a view of San Francisco
author: Veronica C.

description:
A great spot for hiking!! It was pretty cold and gloomy when we went, which I think is the perfect weather to hike. It's a small walk uphill and once you get to the top, the view is amazing! The pictures definitely don't do it justice. You get a 360 view of the entire city!! 

Once you walk into the woods, you'll find a huge cross. It's a monument for the Armenian genocide. It's a really cool sight, surrounded by the trees. There are little trails within the woods so you can do some exploring. 

I highly recommend it if you're in SF!
author: Vy T.

description:
Highest natural point in San Francisco? 

This place is a really nice place for pictures and a breath of fresh air, but it is no hike. There's two places you can start from, either from the bottom of the forest or near the bus stop in the back. Walking from the bottom during a foggy day makes you feel like you've stepped into another world away from SF. Overgrowth on tall trees with rays of sunlight piercing the thick fog and tree canopy. My ideal type of hike right there. I came in from the back with a couple of friends. If you walk a few minutes up, you're already there. Views you can see from here are the Sutro Tower, Twin Peaks, and the entire eastern half of San Francisco. Honestly I think views on Grand View Park or Twin Peaks have nicer panoramic views of the city, but I loved it here too.

Definitely come here for the giant cross, and the famous fallen tree! The cross is massive in size, and the tree is fun for climbing. Great photo opportunities all around. You might need a buddy to help you to sit on top of the branch. Trust me the branches are more than sturdy enough for the average guy.
author: Kevin S.

description: Great location for photos in SF!! Not a huge park but many varied scenes for photos - interesting tree, huge cross, lots of greenery, view of the city. I went yesterday for an instameet and if you go around 9am the fog is there so you can get some interesting shots. Only downside is the location is not the easiest to get to.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
Beautiful breathtaking place!!!! So obsessed with the view..
Just look at the pictures
author: Amy V.

description:
One of my favorite views of the city, less crowded than Twin Peaks. 

Take a 5 minute "hike" up Mt. Davidson and you will be rewarded with one of the best views of the city. This walk is a bit rocky with stairs, so don't go wearing your Tory Burches up here like I did the first time! You will then reach an open area and see an amazing view of the city. Equally beautiful during the day and night. Once, I came on a foggy day and it was a whole different experience. It was as though I was floating in the clouds. The city lights at night are also a sight. The one thing I like the most is that it is never crowded. I think all three times I came here, we were the only ones up there so it's nice and quiet. Just you and the view. 

Tip: If you choose to come up here at night, it's a VERY dark hike up. With stairs. Be sure your phone is charged so you can use the flashlight.
author: Jen P.

description: I'm not sure about hiking where there are coyotes but I love the view here. You can see the view of all the houses and also the big branch that people take lots of pictures at. If you go a little bit higher, you can see a cross. It's cool that you can take a look at how fast the fog is moving into the city.
author: Phuong N.

description: This is a great place to come for a view while avoiding  the crowds of Twin Peaks.  There are a few different entrances but the main one closest to the view is on Myrna Way at Lansdale Avenue.  The trails are more of a walk than hike but if you wanted to make it a hike park at the bottom of Dalewood and walk up, it's extremely steep and a good workout.   What I like most about Mt Davidson is that part of it is very forested so I feel as if I'm out of the city in the woods.
author: Joan W.

description: Great views of SF and the bay bridge! Love it!
author: Ray O.

description:
Arrived here in the fog as it began to clear up. It is a short hike and kid friendly. I saw a group of kids in little vests  with their dad when I went and they were adorable. It is muddy during the winter season so I advise you wear shoes that you won't mind getting dirty.

I didn't get to explore the entire park and simply went to the top to see the tree and the view. It was worth it and amazing. Dogs are allowed as long as they are on leashes and there is a bench where the tree is if you decide you want to sit down on something other than the tree.

I don't get how people  manage to sit near the tip of the branch. You all are intense tree-climbers  ( in which I am not). Definitely a good place to immerse yourself in forestry. It is beautiful even in the fog.
author: Jessica Q.

description:
This place isn't really a hike, but it is a nice walk and a nice place to take photos of SF since you can see the downtown area from far away. It gets chilly while walking uphill and I went the day after it rained, so the floor was super muddy and wet still. 

The huge cross was tall and dirty, and it's amazing how the monument lasts so long throughout these years. Very cool cross though! I also walked towards the famous tree with multiple branches sticking out. It's a struggle to get on the branch and sit on top of the branch, but it's doable! Just need to use them abs and have a person help out. The branches are really smooth so you can't really fall. I was scared cause to me it seemed really high up! This park is a nice place to just chill and I recommend tourists to come see the cross.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Nice hike to top of the highest natural point in Bay Area and the Mount Davidson memorial cross. 

Near panoramic views. Multiple back dirt trails. Caution, slippery after rain.

(This entry written by husband)
author: Yonnie C.

description:
I'm not sure I would call the walk up a hike since it takes maybe 10 minutes at most, but there's a really nice view of SF from the top. The place doesn't seem as well known so there aren't as many people here, even on the weekend, which is perfect if you want to climb the dead tree and take your time taking pictures.

For those of you who want to get pictures on the tree, it's actually not that high up, but it's not quite as easy as it looks to climb. Or maybe it was just me that struggled a lot..

There's a few options for you to get up the tree:
1. Climb up the side/trunk - Unfortunately, the trunk of the tree is incredibly smooth and slippery and my shoes lacked the traction for me to safely climb up that way without sliding down
2. Have a friend hoist you up - Assuming you came with a friend to take pictures for you. I rejected this option because I stubbornly wanted to get up by myself
3. Hoist/swing yourself up - I opted for this option and rather ungracefully swung my legs up and around the branch to get up
4. Bring a stool or something else to stand on - I wish someone had told me this beforehand..

The branch shakes pretty easily so if it's windy up there, it might be a little scary sitting up there! There's also a giant cross further up the hill.
author: Jessie L.

description:
Easy hike! Took my parents along and it was short. Took about half an hour each way. There's a giant cross you can visit or there is a dead tree which people like to take pictures with. 

This place has an awesome lookout of the city. One of the highest spots in San Francisco. You can even see where twin peaks is located at. 

Dogs are allowed too! Just keep an eye on them.
author: Stephy L.

description:
Great place, better than Twin Peaks and FAR less crowded! BUT, when the fog rolls in, you will freeze!

A must place for any Dirty Harry fan to visit, and you can then wonder how in the heck Inspector Callahan was supposed to get to here in such a short time from the marina. 
Ahh, the Hollywood reality!
author: George T.

description:
A great hike and hidden gem of San Francisco. The same amazing views as twin peaks but way less people. You are really feel more out in nature than you do in the parking lot of twin peaks.

While people go for the hike and views, it is also worth going all the way up to see the giant commemorative cross at the peak.

Just like everywhere else in San Francisco, if it is not bright and sunny, bring a jacket!
author: Ryan J.

description:
Mt Davidson has views that are as great as Twin Peaks but without the crowds. Like Bernal Heights the only way to get up here is to walk. But in this case you'll be hiking up through trees. The view only appears at the top where it will surprise you - along with the giant cross.

Many people don't know about the giant cross because it faces southwest so it's not visible from the center of town. It's a massive monument to the Armenian genocide in Turkey. Apparently it was also featured in Dirty Harry.

Now that I've been up Mt Davidson I've finally covered the "the Seven Hills of San Francisco"(Telegraph Hill, Nob Hill, Russian Hill, Rincon Hill, Mount Sutro, Twin Peaks and Mount Davidson). It only took me 9 years!
author: Jean K.

description:
Definitely worth a stroll up if you're in the neighborhood! There are entrances all around the base of the mountain and they're all different. Some are winding and wooded, others are large enough for a vehicle and climb right to the top. The further uphill your trail entrance, the easier the hike will be. If you want more of a challenge, look for a trail near the bottom. I started at the bottom, came out near the top and it took an hour, including photographs. 

There are so many side trails thought that you could spend a lot more time wandering around if you wanted to. In general, trails that go more or less straight will take you around the mount to see all the different views. But be warned that this trail was narrow and rocky at times. It does require that you pay attention and be careful. There are others that split off and go up to the top or down to the bottom in a more direct route. You'll get to the top regardless and there are wonderful picture views up there.
author: Angelique L.

description: Beautiful easy stroll. I wouldn't call it a hike, but it definitely has the views of sf to daly city when you reach the top. Not to mention, a huge cross....
author: Judy L.

description:
We visited on a foggy/drizzly weekday morning in late February & had the entire place to ourselves.  The relatively short (approx 1-mile round trip) & easy walk up was quiet except for the many birds, whose various calls & fluttering about actually added to the overall peaceful atmosphere of the morning.  

When we reached the top, the panoramic view of the city was unsurprisingly obscured by fog, but that was beautiful in it's own SF kind of way.  A little bit farther uphill & a bit into the woods, the enormous cross rises up.  It's much larger in person than I expected.  And in the quiet, gloomy morning, against the fog, the towering cross can be a tad intimidating.

There are several smaller, beautiful, verdant paths near the monument, one in particular with stone steps, that is definitely worth exploring.  

But the coolest thing you should know about Mount Davidson is the "Ransom Run" scene in Dirty Harry was filmed here! https://youtu.be/soZZ_agKT8E  

I really enjoyed this park; it's really beautiful & part of SF iconic film history.  Highly recommend if you're in the area!
author: Kel E. B.

description:
If you would to go to a place to see a very huge cross and grand view of the city, then Mount Davidson Park is the place for you, my friend.

We luckily found parking exactly right in front of the pathway that leads you to the park. The first thing we noticed is that there is sign warning of sighting of coyotes. So be careful. Haha

There's like two pathways that you can take which takes thru to both points-- the area where you can enjoy the view of the city & the other spot where there lies a large cross. I'm pretty sure if you're really religious, you would feel more in tune with such statue. But even though I'm not really religious, it was still neat to see this really big cross.

While we were there, there were many people who would bring their dogs to go hiking with them. If I was to bring my Moki, she would just plop every other couple minutes. Haha

This was a great place to visit to make it a Sunday Funday :)
author: Amy C.

description:
Simply Put:
- Beautiful view of the city
- There's a muni stop at the bottom of the hill
- great for pictures
- it's not really a hike, more like a small 5 minute uphill stroll 
- there were coyote warnings when we went. just be careful :)
author: Mindy Y.

description:
Something worth depriving sleep over. Woke up at 5:15 and caught a Lyft line here for $11. 

One mistake I did do was actually do a actual legit hike up the mountain versus knowing that there was a straight shot up the mountain on the other side near the bus stop. We had to use your iPhone lights to guide ourselves up at such a early morning time with it being dark out and foggy. 

But when we get up there it was well worth the hike and exercise. Do some research on iPhone as to when is the actual sunrise for the best views. I recommended getting 15-20 minutes there prior get a couple of use one with the nightlights still over San Francisco and a couple of the sunrise,

All in all I think this is a must do for all visitors into San Francisco.
author: Angel S.

description: What a fantastic, underrated hike in SF! The panoramic, unobstructed views of the bay and the city are incredible. We started our hike on the unmarked trail off of Dalewood Way, and during the initial hike you'll forget you're in the city. We hiked through eucalyptus forests lined with vibrant green ferns and ivy. Once you circle around the ridge you'll be surprised with a glimpse of the bay, and as you continue your hike up the view gets even better. This hike is a round trip 1.5 miles. It's a moderate, pretty quick hike and it's definitely worth the view from the highest peak in SF (938 ft). Don't forget to bring your dog because this place is dog-friendly, but leashes required.
author: Caroline S.

description:
One of SF's many hidden gems. The "hike" is short and sweet, and the magnificent view of the city and the rest of the bay is a breath-taking reward. The trees that surround the peak of Mt. Davidson are magical when shrouded in fog with palpable sun rays peeking through. I love taking visitors here, because it is epic whether the conditions are sunny or foggy. Bring your camera; this is the highest natural point in SF!

The gnarly tree at the top has its very own hashtag on Instagram, hahah, called #thatSFtree. During a storm 2-3 years ago, the tree got knocked down, but it's still as photogenic as ever on its side. It's also more climb-able too ;] 

There are many trailheads where you can enter the park. I usually like to park at the intersection of Landsdale and Dalewood. There are two benches at the top, if you want to spend some time enjoying a sandwich while pontificating life.
author: Tuwie N.

description: Nice park with good short uphill hikes and great views from top, we enjoy it with our dogs from time to time.  Writing to try to spur the city to do some forest management, particularly in the area of the trails leading from Juanita Way.  Vines have been allowed to grow up and around the trunks of most of the tall Eucalyptus trees, in time they will kill those trees if they haven't already.  The dead trees will fall across the trails, hopefully when no one is around.  Also the underbrush hasn't been cleared in a couple of years, when it gets dry that will be a fire hazard, and in any case it creates an unsightly hazard (lots of thorns).  The PRD generally does a great job of maintenance in the parks but this area feels very neglected and is not being properly managed for long run forest health.
author: Kerry K.

description: One of the most underrated spots in the city. The 103-foot white cross at the top has a ton of history over the Easter Sunday of the mid-20th century, and of course you should go for your picture of #thatSFtree with an amazing overlook of the city at large, as well as views over the East Bay and south towards San Bruno. You can easily spy on people at the top of Twin Peaks and near the Sutro Tower too! Easy climbs to the top.
author: Andy L.

description:
This park gives an amazing view of the city! It's a very short and easy stroll to the top. I almost felt bad for looking at such an amazing view when I didn't even have to walk that much to get there.

There is a cool looking dead tree at the top where people sometimes climb and take photos. On the other side of the park (this depends on where you start walking up) there is a cross.
author: Theresa L.

description:
We loved our little walk to Mt. Davidson. It is beautiful and pretty easy.

Note that if you use the address listed here on YELP that is puts you really close to the cross. We were not aware of that and ended up walking around after making it up to the cross. There are lots of little trails and paths to check out, we didn't get too lost, but did end up having to talk up the biggest hill I have ever seen. We felt very accomplished after and hungry :-P
author: Meghan L.

description:
Went to Mount Davidson for the first time today and loved it. As a potato, this was a nice place to walk and get a nice view of the city. At the entrance, there were 3 walking sticks, I'm assuming, that were left by previous hikers which made me think this would be a difficult hike. I took one with me just in case, but did not need it because the hike was so easy peasy. Walking up and down the hill took me less than half an hour at a slow, comfortable pace.

I came here on a sunny day and didn't need any layers, but I would recommend still bringing a light jacket just in case Karl the Fog comes around plus you are shaded by trees. Some of the ground was wet and muddy so be aware of where you step. 

At the top of the hike, you could see a grand view of downtown, Sunset district, and Bay Shore which was breathtaking. There is a dead tree that you could climb and take rad pictures!! There is also a big cross that several people were hanging out and reading books. 

Definitely coming back here again!!
author: Cindy M.

description: One of the last sanctuaries left in sf to find some peace and quiet and take a hike on some good nature trails. There's a huge cross at the top also for all the Christians and Catholics out there.
author: Sebastian M.

description: I have yet to get to the top of Mt Davidson. We did go for a hike to see where the trailhead was and Google map took us on this long circuitous walk from city street up a steep hill which gave me palpitations.  We passed the main entrance and circled around to 2 other pathways which were farther away and heading back down the mountain and the 3rd path was even narrower in. We will need to find a day to get an early head start. Don't use Google map. They take you to a long route when you can do a short cut from near Portola where Starbucks and Round Table pizza are located.
author: Ry T.

description: Great hike with a very beautiful view of the city. Be careful on the trails as the rocks are a bit slippery at some points. There is a nice tree on the top of the hill for pictures. Climbing the tree is easy but getting off may be a bit tricky. In my experience, the best way is to slide it down. Yes, slide down the tree. It may sound a bit crazy, but it works. Above the hill with the tree is the giant cross. This hike has several trails that all lead to the top. If the path splits off and you are not sure if it is a trail then do not go on it. It will most likely lead to a dead end and you will have to go back. DO NOT go off the trail and try to create your own shortcut. There are a bunch of thorns everywhere and you will only be hurting yourself and nature. I had a friend who did that because he went off on a trail that led to a dead end and tried to make a shortcut back to the main trail. He came back with cuts everywhere. Overall, an easy hike if you stick on the main trail and always go up. Also, this hike could definitely benefit from having signs.
author: Dang L.

description:
Love this park, although it's really more of a small forest with several trails. 

What a magical, wonderful escape from the city. It only takes a few steps to transition from the urban setting and "into the wild".
author: Nina M.

description:
This place is soooo pretty. It shouldn't be considered a hike, because it's more like a stroll to the top, where there's an amazing view of the City. There are several trails that you can take, and honestly, they're all really nice! It's not too crowded here, so it's pretty nice. I love this place, and I'd definitely come back here! The struggle of a 5'1/2" feet person to climb on that one branch of the famous tree was definitely hard though, hahah. 

on the downside, IT WAS HARD FOR US TO FIND THE ENTRANCE TO THIS PLACE. We followed the "Mount Davidson" on Google, but we didn't see an entrance... Haha. It was a little bit hard to find, but not too bad after driving around for a bit.
author: Janet L.

description:
FYI this is not really a hike. 

I don't know where we got the idea that it was, but we made the effort to wake up early on a Saturday, came fully geared and ready to sweat, only to take a 15 minute stroll straight to the top. In this kind of situation, you can't even pretend it was a workout.  

Nevertheless, it was a beautiful panoramic view of the entire city and most definitely worth it. Considering how easy it is to get here, I can see why it's a destination for so many photographers. And as predicted, we did see someone with a tripod at the top.

If anything, Mount Davidson is probably better for a run since there are multiple short trails around the park. It wasn't that crowded (even for a Saturday!) so this might just be the perfect escape from the pedestrian-filled sidewalks and roads of SF! Plus it's always nice to go running somewhere with a view!
author: Junes S.

description: There are many entrances throughout to enter Mount Davidson Park. The entrance that we started from was Rockdale and Myra. There are stairs in the residential neighborhood that lead up to the trail. It is a bit hard to notice initially, but look for the cobble step stairs. There is plenty of parking near the entrance in this area. Initially when you hike up, the trail is very narrow and you brush against the bushes, but the trail widens as you head in. This a fairly easy hike and not too crowded of a destination. The trails in this park are not marked, but you can figure out your way with Google Maps. It took us maybe 15 minutes to get to the top. The two main locations that people tend to go to on this hike is the giant cross and vista viewpoint, which was where we hiked to. The cross is humongous, over 100 feet tall, one of the tallest crossest. Mount Davidson is known as the highest point in SF, so naturally, there are amazing views here. For the view, head over to vista viewpoint, which is very close to the cross. There is a fallen tree in the viewpoint area, where many people like to take pictures. It can get windy, so bring a jacket. It is definitely worth it to go to the vista viewpoint and it wouldn't take you long at all.
author: Julia K.

description:
If you are looking for a mini forest hiking adventure within confines of SF, look no further than Mount Davidson Park (Mount Sutro is also an excellent alternative).

You don't have to drive far to one of its several entrances, the one we chose was close to Dalewood Way and Lansdale Ave. Once you start the hike, you're transported to lush greens and tall trees. It's hard to believe we have this gem right in the middle of a bustling city! You'll traverse through the 'forest' for about a mile, slightly inclining as you go, until you exit the forest and are rewarded with gorgeous sweeping views of the city, as you wrap around the mount, the view reveals more neighborhoods. You can really take a deep breath and appreciate the beauty of SF here! Hike another quarter mile and the incline picks up a little more, but not much farther, you've made it! 

The cross atop the mount is a nice landmark. It looks a little eerie on a foggy day for sure. There's a decent area to walk around and appreciate the city before heading down. There's even a cool tree that's gone so famous with its own Instagram hashtag: #thatSFtree. The total like is about 1.5 miles and takes just about an hour.

Bonus star: dog friendly. Woohoo!!
author: Jing D.

description:
I love Mt Davidson, I usually run it. it's short enough that doesn't take too much time, yet the trail is long enough and full of wild life that doesn't feels like you are in the city. 
In the summer and fall it's full of orange flowers (crocosmia) and raspberries. And the city view on the top is very rewarding!

Just a warning, this is not a paved city hike, the trail on the top is almost always a little muddy, you actually need running shoes or some sort of trail shoes to hike comfortably.
author: Mina D.

description: Short hike up, but enjoyed climbing that flimsy tree to take a photo with my friend. Also, I enjoyed walking to the center of the park to find the huge cross and the history placard below it with some history of the location. A short 15-20 minute stroll that's perfect after a meal and to just chat with friends.
author: Amanda C.

description: I absolutely love coming to this beautiful sight! It only takes about 15 minutes to walk to the top, plus it's all shaded by trees. There's also plenty of parking by the street entrance, and the parking is pretty much flat. I highly recommend wearing layers because it's very windy at the top of the mountain! Also, don't even try wearing a hat.
author: Lauren V.

description: You're guaranteed gorgeous views no matter where you are in Twin Peaks.  Mt. Davidson is a famous landmark for the giant cross monument.  The hiking trails around Mt. Davidson Park will give you beautiful panoramic views of the city.  As far as the hiking trails go, there are a few short ones that all intersect at some point.  The inclines can be a little steep but nothing too strenuous.  The trail is about a mile long.  Parts of the trail are shaded.  The trail heads are right off the street of the residential neighborhood.  Check it out a nice day.
author: Liv A.

description: Sick park in the middle of the city. The path is pretty muddy on the way up due to the fog. The path back down was a little treacherous as well. But the view was breathtaking! Wear shoes you're willing to get dirty.
author: Jon C.

description:
The friend I climbed up Mount Davidson with asked, "Do you think we appreciate the view less because the hike up was so easy?"

"Absolutely not!" came my reply.

At 928 feet (283 m) it is the highest point in San Francisco and affords visitors a lovely view of the city's skyline on a clear day. And the best part? The climb up is easy enough that anyone with the ability to walk up a couple flights of stairs can tackle its ascent with ease.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Beautiful place but I have to say... 

Dog Owners: There's a sign at the entrance to keep your dog on it's leash. I am so tired of people's yappy, annoying dogs running at me and bothering me while their slow owners are nowhere to be seen. This has happened on several occasions. If you're too unfit to keep up with your dog, try finding a trail you can handle. Also, obey the signs and stop ruining it for others. Not everyone likes your mangy mutt.
author: Emma M.

description:
Easy hiking.  And so empty!  Certainly more birds than people.  Another beautiful refuge, much like Mt. Sutro, that is almost abandoned by the San Francisco populace.  The trails are clean and maintained.  You'll probably cross paths with a couple of people and possibly canines, but you won't have to battle crowds.

The monument for the Armenian genocide is very beautiful, as are the several scenic vistas.  As are alllll of the trees. It's so wonderful, and peaceful, and pleasant smelling.  A bit of a jaunt from the Forest Hill station but well worth it.
author: Pernicious J.

description:
The views are great up here. You have a great view of Twin Peaks and Sutro Tower in addition to a panoramic view of San Francisco and the neighborhoods South/West of town. The giant cross is a nice monument and its location back in the woods is a great spot for some quiet reflection. Now I notice the cross all the time poking up just above the trees.

I think I took the hard way up, it made for a tough but short hike through the woods from the North side of the park.
author: Robert S.

description:
Worth the Climb!

It was terrible weather, and the climb was tougher than expected.  That slowed us down a bit, but it didn't stop us.  Even in lousy weather, it is a great climb and a wonderful park.
author: Ted Q.

description:
This spot is great.  The "hike", if you really even can call it that, was super super easy and short.  To be fair, my boyfriend and I were confused as to where to park and where to enter, so we drove up this CRAZY STEEP mountain/hill...that may have been the reason why the hike was so short and easy.  We bypassed the hard part (haha)!

After entering the woods and traveling on an obvious trail for some time, we walked up the steps to this huge cross, and then the land leveled out.  We, then, walked toward a magnificent view of the city.  There were like two separate areas where you had different views.  The higher up one: You were obviously higher up, so you could see more of the city and have more of a bird's eye view.  The slightly lower area: you could see the city more/closer, and you had a different view to the left.

Overall: It's a great place to spend an hour or so soaking in the beauty of SF.  I think it would be a great idea to have a picnic there and relax.  Everybody should definitely go :)
author: Courtney C.

description:
My oh my. I traveled my little booty from Seattle to check out this point. Thanks to the wonderful world of social media, I peeped this place from someone's Instagram and was super excited to come. 

The "hike" up takes like 5 minutes, tops. And it's a gorgeous little hike. Depends on which side you come up, but there's plenty of parking in the neighborhood around. I got a nice dose of San Fran hills driving up to here, haha but this place is a must! 

The view is absolutely gorgeous. You can see just about every part of San Francisco all from one point and it is jaw dropping on the views to take pictures. There's the giant cross that's super easy to find as well. 

I wish I lived in San Fran because I would definitely visit this place all the time. 

This is a must stop at!
author: Melanie R.

description: Short little hike that leads to a beautiful view of sf! Great for those who don't like steep and long trails. There are different trails but the fastest way to the top is through the path on the right side once you enter. It literally took me ten minutes to get to the cross.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Now don't come here expecting something like Golden Gate Park...but if you like to hike and enjoy awesome views of our great city-by-the-bay, you'll enjoy meandering through some of the shady trails and stepping over old fallen trees.

You'll score cool-points with kids, dogs and dates in this serene setting. The hike up the hill is just enough to take off the high heels for (I always do lol) and once you reach the top, you'll swear that ol' Dirty Harry is hanging around somewhere looking for the bad guy.

The memorial underneath the cross is a worthwhile stop, and the story told about the Armenian Genocide during 1915-23 is one that needs to be told to everyone.
author: John H.

description: Short 10 minute walk to a fantastic view of The City. Beautiful during a nice warm day. Take wooden stairway that leads to the Sunrise Easter Cross...a place of serenity and spirituality.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
This was a weird hike for me. For one, it was broken up. I felt like there wasn't a continuous trail that you could choose. There were so many off paths but not really one main one. This lead us to go in circles. The hike is short and it might just be that type of hike. Unfortunately I was looking for something a bit longer and a clearer pathway. The view up top is great, though. Great views of the neighborhoods and the city. There are also not many people on this hike, which is a plus if you don't like being followed or trailing people.

It's definitely a walking hike - no bikes since the hike is pretty rocky and narrow. But, hey, I'm glad I went on it. It's all about exploring and learning!
author: Junel S.

description:
THE VIEW IS AMAZING! 

My friend took me to Mt. Davison on a sunny morning. We took the 43 bus and got off at Miraloma Dr and Junita Way. When you get off the bus you can see a whole bunch of trees up top on a mountain, that looks like a forest up there!

When we got to the entrance of one of the paths, we took pictures and then began the hike up! The hike up isn't difficult at all and as you are walking through, you can see a lot of trees and nature all around. All the paths eventually intertwine with each other, so it isn't as likely to get lost. Definitely a change of scenery compared to all the buildings that we see around the city. 

The view at the top is simply AMAZING! BREATHTAKING! We were able to see all the buildings, houses, and even the bay bridge! There are even stair paths that lead down to get "closer" to the sight. My friend told me that on a foggy day, you can't see all the view of the city but it is still a great experience!
author: Jeanette Q.

description:
Was in West Portal for Stern Grove festival and wanted to do a little hike beforehand. It's a good walk between so that's bonus excercise!

Easy to get here from downtown- take the K, L, M to West Portal and head east on Portola about half a mile and you're there. It was a beautiful sunny day so perfect for a hike. Nice eucalyptus trees I think? I saw dogs also. Not too many people here. When you get to the top, depending on which trail you use, you'll see the huge cross that commemorates Armenian genocide. What a sight! On the other end you'll see amazing view of San Francisco and Sutro tower. Wowzers. Hiking back down this way was a little treacherous and slippery so watch out for that (we may not have had the right shoes). 

Anyways, it's a really awesome park with nice trails. And great views! And a huge cross :)
author: Vol T.

description:
Where is the love for Mount Davidson Park? Everyone raves about Twin Peaks but I prefer Mount Davidson by a landslide! More parking, unobstructed photos, and fewer tourists - what is not to love about this place? 

On top of that, you have better scenes / photo opportunities including but not limited to: bench at the end of the walkway, dead tree looming over the walkway, bench on top of the mountain and the secret cross behind you in the trees.
author: E E.

description:
I once saw the very tip of this cross from the West Portal neighborhood and wondered how the heck to get up there. 
Recently I've been very in to urban hikes...get off at a random BART station and then map out an interesting location from there.
This time around my boyfriend and I got off at Glen Park. From there it was about 1.5 mile walk to Mount Davidson. The walk there in itself is pretty good workout. You're walking up hill almost the entire time and can turn around and catch some pretty amazing views from atop streets like Teresita and Buena Vista on the way up.

Once we got to the park, we took the first trail up that we saw, which wasn't that strenuous of a climb. We took in the bay and downtown views as well as the great views of the Sutro Tower and Twin Peaks. Fortunately it was a crystal clear day so that made it all the more glorious. Still feeling like walking more we took some of the trails that wind down through the forested area and once you reach a certain a point, you forget you're in San Francisco-quiet and green with small winding trails. Then you turn a corner and you can see the houses below. Back up again towards the top wasn't that challenging but got a little bit of a glute and calf burn. That with the fresh air and sunny day just was perfect.

The cross itself, I felt, was pretty awe inspiring. I am not religious in the sense of organized religion, but thought it was a pretty magnificent monument. Surrounded by the trees, I did feel a certain reverance for it. Any naysayers of it just let it be. 

I wouldn't drive out of my way JUST to come here, but recommend you make an urban hiking day out of it and include this destination on your itinerary. The views are slightly different than up on Twin Peaks and the location itself is off the beaten path from the typical touristy SF areas. 

Lots of friendly people with their dogs and children-the paths were moderate enough where we saw some 5 or 6 year olds clamboring around with no problem.
author: Jennifer N.

description: It is a nice stroll up to the top. You don't have to work too hard to get there. The views up there are amazing.  And at the top there is this Armenian memorial represented in a big cross in remembering the genocide that was perpetrated btw 1915-23.  It's a good view of San Francisco, the ocean, and across the Bay to Oakland.
author: James H.

description: Easy little hike if you are at the entrance near the Muni bus stop.There is another entrance at the bottom where you can find the stairs but we opted to take the easy way up because we were so tired from visiting Alcatraz and Angel Island. Parking was easy. We went on a day where it was really foggy. But we love the fog so it made going here even better. We met an awesome person with his black lab named Chef.He took an cool picture of my husband and I although we couldn't get a nice pic of the cross because of the fog. This place is so cute and I recommend going up the long way if you want to work on your glutes.
author: Mari S.

description: Wonderful views of the city. Be sure to bring lots of warm layers just in case.
author: Gauri B.

description:
I've had memorable Easters before, but my hike in Mount Davidson Park takes the Cadbury.
 
This park feels...divinely inspired.  It's a place with a million stories to tell those willing to listen (No, I'm not tripping out on 'shrooms or E-- the park really does have this great "energy" that I am so drawn to).  

Park features:
-the tallest, most beautiful trees I've ever seen anywhere 
-Nice, short, smart walking trails
-Plenty of intimate spots to meditate or just listen to natural life happening
-Commemorative "sacred" grounds with a cool history (even for non-believers)
-An august, panoramic, sweeping view of the entirety of San Francisco and beyond

Such a great find!  I'd go daily if I hadn't sneezed for 2 days afterwards...
author: Brendan S.

description: I live 10 min walk from Mount Davidson and love taking the dogs up. It's like going on vacation with them 3-4x week.
author: Rose H.

description:
I live really close to the park, it's a great place to hike. It's not as crowed as other places, once you get on the top, you would appreciate the view of San Francisco. Be careful, sometimes it just gets real foggy, you'd better be prepared. I would suggest go there at the afternoon, the sunset view is cool. 

I went there to watch the fireworks last July 4th, it's not a very good idea, one of the mountains block part of the fireworks, but I'm ok with that since there were a lot less people than other firework-watch places.
author: Dave Z.

description: it's a remarkable spot you could see entire downtown already has expanded over the years to Sue's of different path you could go and view 360° view of San Francisco
author: Jack D.

description: A beautiful mix of being locked into the video game "Legends of Zelda",and a really vivid experience on acid.Love roaming
author: Lauren V.

description:
This park was a suggestion from my wonderful girlfriend for Sunday afternoon stroll. It's secluded enough to have an intimate walk and conversation with a friend/date. However, not too secluded that you'll find yourself thinking you're in a horror film waiting to happen and your massacred body ending up on the 6pm news. 

Check out the fallen tree for some great tree swinging and then pay your respects to the giant cross that serves as a memorial for lives lost in the Armenian genocide. 

Oh yeah -- and if you don't already know -- the view of the city is just amazing.
author: Malori M.

description:
Great spot! The view is totally 5 stars. The hike is moderate to easy. I brought two of my babies with me (dogs). Hahahah, we ubered there! But, I enjoyed it. I didn't run into Coyotes even though there is a disclaimer that few have seen them. So many random paths to take. One path lead me back to the streets, but I was determined to find the cross! Which we did! beautiful hike.

There were little stems with thorns on the narrow "hidden paths"; so if you're walking with a dog, it's best to bring tweezers and clippers just in case.
I didn't run into anyone until I got to the cross. I was like, where the hell did they come from? 4 stars because there was a BIG ASS dog without its owner. Like those MASTIFF DOGS sitting on the streets. I know he was relaxing but he let out one big bark as we quietly walked past. ... AND I was nervous it'd come towards me and eat me for breakfast, and my dogs for snacks. lol jk. So -1 star for that.
author: Sweets N.

description:
Great urban/not-so-urban hike!

A quick ~2.25 mile run from my house, it's relatively small for a park, (we ARE spoiled in the bay area with all the great parks) but it has some good trails and hill training.
Ran here & had to get through some gnarly people traffic by City College, but once I actually got to the park it was me & two other dog walkers. The dogs outnumbered humans! And after 15 mins, I was all by myself...kinda unheard of in the City. Incredibly. peaceful & an excellent place to do some yoga & stretch while enjoying the view. Been here a few times now, and it's a good place to have a cheap date, take people from out of town, or to just get some quiet time.
author: Elena P.

description: This is one of my favorite spots to picnic in San Francisco. It is quiet save for a few locals hiking and walking their dogs. Absolutely zero tourists, and a spectacular view of downtown, Oakland, the bay and eastern and southeastern San Francisco. Some days can be a bit windy and chilly, so just remember your jacket and you will be golden.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Highest point in San Francisco (I guess people think those honors belong to Twin Peaks for some reason). Mt. Davidson is an absolute gem in SF. It offers some pretty killer views of East and downtown SF. You can whip out your iPhone and take some panorama photos and show off to all your friends what a beautiful city you live in.

The main attraction here is a huge cross owned by an Armenian organization. The cross is surrounded by a grove of trees, which offer some much needed solitude from the bustling urban life below. For a bonus, put on some LOTR music or something while strolling through Mt. Davidson. You will feel epic.
author: Dan K.

description: My favorite spot in all of San Francisco. If you're interested in more of the history, check out mtdavidson.org.
author: Dana F.

description:
Pretty, easy hike! More for scenic adventures! The coolest part was reaching the big cross in the middle of nowhere!!! It was beautiful :) A pleasant surprise :) 

There are a lot of trails leading to random directions and some are really muddy so bring proper shoes!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Very pretty hike! Small, but nice and awesome views of the city. Better than twin peaks since its always crowded with tourists. 

The cross itself was beautiful and represent the Armenian genocide. Sad to see beer bottles and trash around the place since I'm guessing certain locals take advantage of the isolated park. 

Has numerous trails surrounding it though, can be muddy so wear comfortable shoes.
author: Nika K.

description:
Easy hike with great views of the city. It's most recognize by the film Dirty Harry as the hill with the cross on top. There are many trails leading in different direction but it is all circular leading to the top where the cross stands.  Dogs are allowed on leash. 

We did Glenn Canyon before had since it was close by and got more of a good hike in.
author: Maverick W.

description: Beautiful place. You get the wind and sometimes the fog blowing in. Depending what path you take, it is either a vigorous hike or a nice smooth uphill hike. The views are worth it as well as the giant cross on top of the hill. it's partially hidden behind the trees.
author: Cesar P.

description: It was moderately hard for us to find the trail but once we did, it was a pleasant hike with a lot of shades and the view up top was absolutely stunning. Pro tip: bring a vietnamese roasted pork sandwich from Saigon Sandwich (TL, San Francisco) with you and eat it once you make it to the top. You'll be everyone's envy.
author: Anji S.

description:
This place is so easy to find and worth the while if you love hikes. I came with a group of friends and we were completely lost. There weren't really any signs, so you basically had to pick and choose your way up the mountain. With all that nature around you, you can't help but stop and appreciate all those trees and flowers! (Partially because you're out of breath too)

But the cross is definitely something remarkable and meaningful. At the top of the mountain there is breathtaking view of the city. Definitely worth coming back over and over!
author: Olivia B.

description: Mount Davidson is the highest natural point in SF and has great views just like Twin Peaks but not as well known. It requires a small easy hike. It's only about a 10 minute walk and we did it several times with young kids. It's rocky so watch your step and wear good hiking shoes. Awesome to see the view and the giant cross.
author: Stacey L.

description: Took the dog to the mountain today- it's a short hike, but beautiful views of the bay. There were very few people so it was quiet and there are many little trails to roam around with a gorgeous view.
author: Samantha H.

description:
Love love love this place!

Had been wanting to check it out for a long time...ever since I saw "Dirty Harry" and wondered where that gigantic cross was in SF. Look no further than Mount Davidson Park!

We parked on the opposite side of the park entrance (I think), on a residential street where we saw some brick stairs that ascended up the hillside. It's amazing how when you're hiking in the canopy of trees you can for a second forget you're in the middle of SF. It's a pleasant hike, as you approach the summit you get glimpses of the cross through the trees. The cross stands in this huge clearing and it's really awe-inspiring. But wait, there's more!

The view of SF is marvelous! A different perspective than Twin Peaks, but just a amazing. Check it out for sure!
author: Greg S.

description: Decided to visit Mount Davidson with my Bon Bon after receiving updates about its location through Instagram. I must say this little hidden jewel is definitely  great place to clear your mind and find peace! I loved the different pathways that were locate through out the park and the cross on top of the hill was an eye soar! Two words Love It! I will be going again!
author: Andrew J.

description: Me and a few friends came up here last night, it's the eerie feeling at night of the cross of the genocide, but it's a pleasant view from the top since you can see all of beautiful san francisco.
author: Chris R.

description:
Came here for a little urban hiking while in the city,  but it was such a foggy day that there was zero visibility from the top :(( 

Was expecting a beautiful view, but I guess I would have to plan another day when it's sunny and clear.  The trail was wet, but we were able to navigate around muddy areas. There didn't seem to be many people on the trail, and only came across 2 females walking.   When we got to the top, it felt peaceful and quiet-- with the huge cross and trees towering over, and the fog slowly creeping and enveloping everything around you. It was sort of eerie and mystical at the same time, especially when the church bells nearby started to ring. 

It's about less than a mile to the top where the cross is and the trail is fairly easy.  There were stairs on the trail but nothing a beginner can't handle.  

Wonderful, quiet place for some solitude (if no one is there), meditation, some soul searching, or penance lol. You can definitely feel a little peace in your heart when you first take sight of the huge cross....will definitely come back.
author: LC B.

description: You would never know you are in a city if it weren't for the spectacular views!  My favorite memory of this little gem of an urban park is from a time I lived on Twin Peaks about 7 years ago - and I walked up through the stairways and neighborhoods - emerging in a clearing where there was a man in a kilt playing bagpipes.  It was one of the most ridiculous things - only in San Francisco, right?  It was surreal and it was a lovely treat.  Enjoy your local urban parks - get some fresh air and exercise - you never know who you will meet!
author: Jenn C.

description:
Through the years, I've seen the cross from different parts of the city but never really knew exactly where it was located.  I always perceived it as this mystical place that could never be reached.  

Finally, this year, I brought myself to make a trip to this mystical place and I was not disappointed.  The cross in the middle of the wooded, foresty kind of area is so majestic and made the environment reach a whole new higher level for me.  If you go on a nice day, you get really nice views of the North and East sides of the city.  Unlike some of the peaks in the city, this one finds itself free from tourists and huge crowds.  It's usually just a couple of dog-walkers and other random somebodies like me curious about this spot.  And it's a perfect place for some major de-stressing.  I have yet to find another equally serene place for me to calm down and recollect myself.  

Some parts of the trail that you take up to the peak can be a bit muddy and slippery at times, especially when there has been some major fog action going on and you're walking back down,  so be careful.  By the end of your hike up the hill, some of you might find yourselves a little exhausted but don't worry - it's all worth it!
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Due to "urban legends", crazy stories about satanic rituals here, it took me forever to finally visit this park.  

The 103 foot cross dominates the skyline from the City College of San Francisco Phelan campus.  At one time the cross was illuminated at night and was visible up to 75 miles away.  

Mount Davidson is named in 1911 after George Davidson who surveyed the mountain in 1862. The original name was Blue Mountain when Adolph Sutro owned the land.   

This is a 38 acre nature preserve. The cross sits atop a 938 foot summit.  There are some steep trails and paths. The view of San Francisco is spectacular.  Mt Davidson is the highest point in the city.

I liked my hike. I will be back.
author: Infodiva B.

description:
My friends and I decided to go on an urban hike and Mount Davidson Park seemed to be the perfect destination.  We met at Glen Park BART station and walked on over to the park.

Unfortunately for us, we didn't really do a whole lot of research ahead of time and figured good ol' Google Maps would lead us the right way. Um. sort of, but not really.  We were led to someone's drive that clearly stated - do not trespass (ie. don't even think about going here to get to the park!).  Woops. Google Maps fail.

Then we mosied around a little bit and found a sort of trail that led us to actual trails to get up to the park. Phew!

The trek up was very pleasant with lush greenery all around.  The top of the park had beautiful views, as everyone said. I like how they do have some benches available to see the views. The way down was a lot easier and we found out where one of the main trail entrances was, which was nice.
author: Naoko M.

description:
When seeking out a panoramic view of the city most folks trek to the top of Twin Peaks, but the Mt. Davidson vista is far superior. Not only can you take in the beauty of our very own concrete jungle, but you can sometimes see all the way to the Golden Gate.

Besides the view, Mt. Davidson serves as the pedestal to a 100ft. cross that commemorates the victims of the Armenian Genocide.

Such an intersection of history and beauty is not a landmark to overlook.
author: Mark O.

description: plenty of parking and easy trail to get up there.  Beautiful view.  Very tranquil and meditative.
author: Helen L.

description:
This is a great place to take someone who has seen all the usual tourist spots. It's a fairly easy hike to the top and there's a couple of different ways of getting there. 

The first time I went up there I wanted to see the big cross but I did not know there were amazing views from the top as well. I had imagined it as a completely wooded area at the top but there's a clearing on the east that provides those spectacular vistas. 

On a side note, I once walked here from the Forest Hill MUNI station and it was a tougher hike getting to the park than actually getting to the cross.  There are some steep streets around there!
author: JD R.

description:
After reading 100 or so review of Mt. Davidson I'm surprised that no one (yet) knows the background of the cross on top. It was *not* placed there by the Armenian community, although they currently manage the immediate grounds surrounding it. 

The cross -- of which this is the fourth version -- originally served two purposes. The first was to show the religious roots of San Francisco -- the city of St. Francis. The second was to serve as a navigational aid to ships off the coast. If you imagine the mountain without any eucalyptus trees -- grrrr!, invasive species!! -- you can also imagine how visible the cross was to offshore vessels. Thus, whether you were on land or at sea, you knew where you were.

Because Mt. Davidson is owned by the city, there was a long debate concerning the cross itself. Is it civic? --secular? --religious? Finally, in the early 1990s, several institutions jointly sued the city in order to force the issue to a resolution, which was to auction the footprint of the cross itself to the highest bidder. A collection of Armenian Christian groups from NorCal won, and paid the city 26K for the right to privately manage that footprint. They then installed the plaque which many Yelpers have noted.

I live on Mt. Davidson and love the area and the park. Why the 4 starts? Bcs the eucalyptus trees need to go. They occlude the view both of, and from, the top, and have completely changed the flora & fauna of the undergrowth.
author: Kern T.

description:
Sweeping panoramic view of the city, being in touch with nature, ginormous light up cross, what more could you want? This place is awesome for smoking with a view or partying in general, which is what most of the fools at my school use it as when they are working on destroying their livers, which is pretty much every weekend. 

It can get a little crowded on the weekends. I once walked (hiked) to the top from the entrance (which itself is pretty sketch looking because it's covered in shrubbery) only to walk back down moments later because I thought I had seen what appeared to be a bunch of neo-KKK members in hoods dancing around the cross. However I should probably note that it was 2am on the Saturday before Easter and they were clearly drunk. In other words, a very SF experience.
author: Lia R.

description: Love taking walks here - it feels like you have left the city... Listen to the chirping birds, the wind blowing in the trees...
author: john s.

description:
When we came here as kids, I thought this place was a major mountain.  A couple miles to a 2.5' tall tyke is a big deal.  It's the same feeling you may have had when you thought your childhood backyard was huge because it could fit a pool and there was a forest (read in adult talk: kiddie pool and 0.02 acres total Noe Valley backyard.)

... much like Mount Davidson.

My Middle eastern blood particularly appreciates the Armenian Genocide memorial.  It reminded me of the Armenian quarters I went to in Jerusalem some 13 years ago.

Check this out if you never have, see where that ginormous cross stems from.
author: Athena S.

description: I absolutely love this place, it is so magical. The hike is super easy, the views are phenomenal and the fog gives this place an eerie mood. I highly recommend coming to this place, if I'm not mistaken this is one of the highest natural points in SF.
author: Ross H.

description: A nice neighborhood park. The views are okay, I still prefer Twin Peaks. On a sunny Sunday afternoon in January the trails were pretty full. Dogs are allowed and the hike is easy. Even with some gratuitous treks down side trails, we made it to the cross and back down in under 40 minutes.
author: Megan S.

description:
Breathtakingly beautiful views.  

I've been thinking about places in my City that are, how should I describe it, mmm. . . mood-changing, in a positive way.  Like, you could be feeling like total crap, but then you arrive at this place, or some place finds you unexpectedly, and then you feel that much better.  The power of place.

This is one of those places.

I've only been here once, but that experience was good enough for me to write a review praising this place.  

It was at least five years ago; I was silly, young, bright-eyed (well, not that I'm not still those things, but I think less so than before) and was packed in a car at 3am in the morning with several other silly, young bright-eyed souls.  Ready for something amazing.  

I don't find myself in this area of the city often, so when the leader of our pack drove us here, I was excited, curious, and as always, ready for a new adventure.  

Things quickly turned sour when we got here, and I realized that it was pitch dark and we'd have to climb through a literal jungle to get to the top.  I started complaining about how ridiculous it was; how it was so dark and late and we were blindly trying to find our way through bushes and twigs and trees to get to lord knows where.  It was all uphill too, and I was getting dirty and couldn't see my way.  So, needless to say, I was not a happy camper.

But.  We eventually got to the top, and here's what I mean by "mood-changing."  

I immediately forgot about how annoyed and irritated I was during the climb.  

Because the view was gorgeous.  I could see EVERYTHING.  All the lights.  The entire city of shining lights against the backdrop of the piercing black night sky.  It was breathtaking.  I couldn't believe we were here, lucky enough to take it all in.  Lucky enough to live here.  You just stand up there, shivering in the cold, but warm from those bubbles that come out of you when you're amazed or overjoyed.  

I've never been up here during the day, but I imagine it's just as awesome.  But I am a fan of the night and the dark and the lights that come with it all.  Maybe you'll find yourself up here too, one of these nights, with your own group of silly, bright-eyed souls.

That view is totally worth the dirty, messy climb anyday.
author: Vivian C.

description:
Calling all urban hikers!  If you're looking for an off-the-beaten path that isn't too stressful and that you can reach by public transportation, check this place out. 

You also will want to tell everyone that you've been to the highest natural peak in San Francisco here at Mt. Davidson. (Sorry Twin Peaks!)

It's located near the geographical center of San Francisco, with plenty of views out to the Pacific Ocean and nearby Miraloma Park. Hopefully the temporary construction will be finished when you reach the peak. But if not, it still offers plenty of views of the downtown skyline and points south, as well as views west and north through the eucalyptus trees all around.

Check out the pics for some of the dramatic scenery. On a clear day it is refreshing and on a foggy day it is magical!
author: Dan S.

description:
This is written from a doggy walk perspective. 
This is a nice short trail up the hill to the cross (you will be up and back in definitely less than one hour). There are a couple of short staircases but generally it is a short, relatively accessible walk. Parking is very plentiful in the neighborhood.
- While this is not challenging, I disagree a little that this is super-easy, absolutely no problem, etc, like many of the reviews say. We had no problems being youngish fit people with an active nimble doggy, but an older person could easily fall on the loose rocks in places. There are no handrails. At the end to get up to the cross, it is a somewhat steep incline on loose dirt. However if you stay on the major trails it's one of the less challenging nature hikes in the city. Wear close-toed shoes since there are little rocks in parts of the walk.
- Dogs have to stay on a leash. Why? 
- The grass and trees are very high on both sides of the trail. So for long stretches you are just walking through high greenery, which does feel very much like being "in the forest" but there's no city view and little variety. Bernal Heights is rocky and dry but the walk is more interesting because the views are spectacular all around. 
- No water fountains and very few picnic or sitting areas. So all there is to do is walk through the high grass/trees and then turn around and walk down.
- Some people are into viewing the cross. Being Buddhists, the huge cement cross with sun rays shining down on it kind of freaked us out. This is a purely personal thing. 
- There should be some trash cans and dog bag stations. We saw a couple of large poops that were not picked up. Dog owners, pick up the poop!
- Doggy enjoyed it a lot but I think she's had a little more fun elsewhere. We would probably go back to Bernal Heights or Fort Funston or Crissy Field before coming here again.
author: p v.

description: Beautiful trails to walk along. All trails usually loop around so no big deal if you get lost. I enjoy the peak views mire than Twin Teaks, feels like you get a better panorama. Dog-friendly, and usually quiet.
author: Alyssa G.

description:
I finally discovered Mount Davidson last Saturday and the cross on top that I've heard so often about. For starters I found I've assumed incorrectly it's location. I kept thinking it's to the west of Portola Drive, not east. I was imagining it was above UCSF. Finally I stand corrected after looking up directions online.

Hiking up there is pleasant. There are two trailheads from Dalewood, allowing us to do a loop hike by going up one way and down the other.  Both trails have moderate grades allowing a bit of workout through elevation gains. I estimate a complete hike using both trails to be about three-quarters if a mile.

The view from top is very nice. Not as good as from nearby Twin Peaks, but very good nonetheless (and at least also minus the crowds). It mainly allows just an eastward view because to the west it's mostly blocked off by trees.

Definitely a worthy place to relax with a view if one desires to just do so by staying within the city.
author: H K.

description:
Cool park hidden in the middle of SF.  Huge freakin' cross.  All sorts of paths to hike on.

Where are the bathrooms in this place?  i guess I'll just go...anywhere.  lol

Kind of a long walk to get to the top.  only for healthy people, not wheelchair friendly.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Another amazing spot in the city, with beautiful views. Great place to escape the busy city scene. So peaceful and breathtaking. First time I saw the cross here, I was creeped out but regardless it is an amazing sight!!
author: Nemesis J.

description: You can almost see forever from up there. Highest natural point in the city. Definitely bring a camera, & some good hiking shoes. Fantastic views. One of the few heavily forested areas in San Francisco.  Lot's of trails fairly easy to walk up since the trails go up in a circular fashion, pet friendly. Nice place for a picnic. Quiet & peaceful, good place to relax.
author: Ron W.

description: It was well worth the bus ride, train ride and hike to get there. Spectacular views of the city. Packed a picnic lunch.Could not believe the size of the cross at the top. Would suggest wearing hiking shoes because trails are muddy in spots. For those with bad knees might even want a walking stick for the trek down.
author: Joe M.

description: beautiful views, you feel a sense of purity while at the cross. love my city. the hike was not intense but its all worth it soaking up this gorgeous city.
author: Sarah N.

description:
A beautiful view of the bay, without all the crowds.


 A true historic landmark.
author: A. B.

description:
I love this park!  I'm amazed that most people I know who live in the city have never been up here.  Granted it is eclipsed by the hype and beautiful views offered by Twin Peaks, but here you actually get walking trails, wildlife, and greenery.  And as many have already mentioned: no tourists, or at least not busloads.
I love to go on city hikes with Mt. Davidson as the starter. Ex:  I walk up from Monterey Blvd, go up Forrester, walk through a bunch of curvy streets, then enter via Dalewood way, take my time enjoying all the views and beautiful trails, then walk down and up Portola Drive and ascend Twin Peaks (both of them), then head down the other side, take Ashbury down to Haight street and grab some coffee at Coffee to the People on Masonic.  Good times.

Side note:  The cross used to be an urban climb spot and had a bolt ladder that ran up to the top.  However, sadly someone died while climbing it and it is no more.   
Also, if you watch Dirty Harry (the first one) there's a pretty long scene of Clint Eastwood chasing the killer up to the top and you can even see the cross.
author: Kevin A.

description: If you like short hikes, you'll love this place! It is a bit muddy but it's not difficult at all and parking is pretty easy to find.
author: Will T.

description: I went here on a nice, sunny day when my parents visited. The hike isn't too difficult, but I do recommend wearing closed-toed shoes. It takes less than 5 minutes to hike up to "the SF tree" and another 5 minutes to the Mt. Davidson Cross. The cross is HUMONGOUS and after the cross, there is more hiking trails. It's a beautiful landscape for pictures and a nice, easy hike.
author: Gina T.

description:
Mount Davidson Park was nice.  That's about it.  That's how your friends probably describe someone that they thought was ok and pretty forgettable.

Not really worth the drive all the way from central SF.  The park itself is really tiny.  We finished hiking around it 2x in less than 25 minutes.  And a lot of the trails were also not well kept and quite muddy.  Perhaps i'm not being fair because it was very windy and foggy, and might have masked part of the views.

The cross was nice and definitely serves as a beautiful memory of the Armenian genocide.  However, unless you're already in the area, I'd say there are lots of other parks in SF to try.
author: Andrea L.

description: A gem of a short urban hike when a dose of nature is the antidote to sanity. Food for the soul with a great view. Hike from trail head to trail head and it's a decent workout, or simply climb the 928 feet to gaze at a lovely vista of San Francisco.
author: Teresa C.

description:
This is a great place to go and still yourself. It is beautiful on sunny days, but you must check it out when it is partly cloudy and there is a mist in the air. Mount Davidson has this foggy mysteriousness about it when it's like this. Make sure you bring a jacket (with a hood), wear layers if you decide to go up there on a day like this (well, if you get cold easily like I do =D). It's really quiet and calm. It's a good place to pop open your Bible and seek Jesus, look up at that big cross, and contemplate or seek out God's love and truth.

Last time I was up there, I went with a couple of friends. I dunno why I don't feel comfortable going up there by myself, but maybe it was because of the foggy mysteriousness and my vivid imagination of creepy people hiding behind the thick forestlike landscape (so, four stars for me).... Otherwise,  it's a great place.
author: Janielle L.

description: Great little spot in the city, short hikes, fantastic views, oddly large cross.
author: Seth W.

description:
I love the giant crazy cross on top of this hill. It's like a secret passage into a completely different San Francisco. 

The views from Mt. Davidson are amazing. It's a great place to take your dogs for a hike, though it's often muddy because the paths are all shady and don't get that drying sunlight.
author: Allison A.

description: I finally made it here and it is really quite spectacular. Fantastic views of ocean, bay, city, etc. I had foot surgery a month ago and have quite the pimp limp at the moment and the hills here were manageable so this is going to be the place to bring my lazy and fat friends to take in some nature and vistas.
