I would equate this to the local's Twin Peaks without all of the tourist buses and crowds and much more forest to meander around and explore. I also brought my dog and although it is required to leash my dog I ran into a few others off leash and they were happy to frolic around and play together!
author: Kristen E.

description:
An excellent and hilly hike!  Mount Davidson Park is the highest point in San Francisco!! How high? Well, I can't tell you that...but my ears did pop climbing up the hills!   There are views of SF here like no other...beautiful at sunrise, gorgeous at sunset!! A phenomenal place to take the dogs for a walk and forget all of your troubles!!   AND its famous for housing the giant  103 foot tall cross as well as the memorial to the Armenian genocide.  (growing up in SF, they used to light the cross up every night!!)  It can be rather muddy up here so wear some shoes with good traction. (there are so many trees that when the ground gets damp from the frequent fog it never really gets enough sunlight to dry out= muddy paths!)  Also, some of the hills are so steep that when you are moseying back down the hill you may want to bring a walking stick or a sturdy  pal to latch onto (yes, the hills are THAT steep...like the Alps of SF I tell ya, I half expected to find some goats and the Ricola guys tucked away up there!)

If you want to take in some great views/ local history, get a bit of cardio and don't mind journeying "off the beaten path"  pay a visit to Mt Davidson Park!
author: Karen S.

description: Great hike on a beautiful Sunday. I was amazed when I saw this. All my time spent in and around the city and never have seen or been here. Definitely a must do.
author: Liz B.

description:
Mt. Davidson is San Francisco's highest natural peak at an elevation of 927 feet. THAT'S ABOVE SEA LEVEL! 

I WISH they would CUT DOWN THE TREES at the top of Mt. Davidson because they obstruct what could be a stunning 360 degree view of the bay area. As it is, the dense eucalyptus trees obstructs views toward the Pacific Ocean and Golden Gate Bridge. I can't see the sea for the forest. The view would be SO MONEY if they'd at least thin out the trees. 

Furthermore, those menacing tall trees also muddle the silhouette of the 103 foot concrete cross when viewed from far distances across the city. Perhaps if they MAKE THE CROSS BIGGER then it wouldn't be an issue. The monument resides on a portion of land that the City auctioned in 1997 to the Council of Armenian-American Organizations, and has since served as a memorial of the 1915 Armenian genocide. A 160-pound bronze plaque commemorating the genocide was once displayed at the base of the cross, but it was discovered missing in 2007. 

From bottom to top, Mt. Davidson is more of a casual stroll that a hiking place. You can ascend to the peak in 10 mins if you walk very slowly. On the clearing, you have a view from SF's downtown to the Oakland ship yard to San Bruno. Easter sunrise services have been held at this site for many years, I think since 1923. 

I'm awed when I look up at the towering cross. The view companied with the solitude and spiritual overtones, yields a good place for some quiet reflection:

"...am I a good person...."
"..........will I make a difference........."
"......where will I be in five years......"
"...can I get cell phone reception here...."
".......I wonder if this place has been yelped yet....."
author: Teddy B.

description:
A very short trail literally in our own back yard! It's only about a mile if you just do the loop, but the landscape is very damp and cool, and can even be a bit muddy when there is consistent fog. It seems like it would be a nice escape on a hot day in the city. You'll see alot of ferns, blackberry brambles, wild strawberries, and ivy everywhere. 

From the top, on a clear day, you can see San Bruno. 

An interesting tidbit: Although the park is owned by the city of San Francisco, the top of the mountain was sold in 1997 to the Council of Armenian-American Organizations of Northern California because of the 100 foot Cross on top, which is a memorial to an Armenian massacre in 1915. 

The sale was to make a clear separation of church and state, which I think is fair, as I do believe strongly in separation of church & state, but I also support freedom of expression. 

The quote at the bottom of the cross reads in both Armenian and English: "If evil of this magnitude can be ignored, if our own children forget then we deserve oblivion and earn the world's scorn." Avedis Aharonian (writer and educator, 1866-1948). 

A suggestion: Stand at the foot of the cross in this open space among all the trees, slightly shrouded in fog, meditate for a second on the efforts of all the people involved in erecting this monument, and look up to the top of the cross. It's a moving experience (and I'm not even Christian). Some seem to think it's an assertation of Christianity, but it's obviously simply a memorial to people who died in a massacre.
author: N B.

description:
Twin Peaks - pshaw!  This is the real top of San Francisco.  I live on the slopes of Mt Davidson and the fact that I can walk or jog through this park right from my front door still amazes me.  The Eucalyptus forest here is incredibly beautiful, especially around sunset with the light coming through the trees.  This is what having an urban forest is about.  Granted, the view isn't as impressive as Twin Peaks, unless you're in love with SFCC & Mt San Bruno.   

Along with Saint Croix Road, there are two great trailheads to approach this from: one at 275 Juanita and one on Rockdale.  Check out Ron Proctor's awesome hand-drawn map: http://www.mtdavidson.org/_detail/mtdavidsontrails.jpg?id=mount_davidson_trail_map&cache=cache
author: Wes M.

description:
twin peaks forgotten older brother, mt davidson is literally my home. this has got to be the foggiest neighborhood in the city. literally some nights i come home, i cant see five feet in front of me, SOLID FREAKING WHITENESS. raspberry bushes basically took over the neighborhood. bushes abound everyfreakingwhere.  i like to take out my lil happy on mt davidson itself. MY DOG happy, you pervs. this is the highest peak in sf, you get some badass views on the top and all without the kids smoking weed  in cars and the blanket of tourist twin peaks has.

it gets a bit muddy up here so you might not wanna where you all white leather 95 airmax with exclusive blue swoosh up here. 

easter, they have sunrise service, surprisingly i havent made *cough* to one yet. cant seem to wake up that early. 

come on a clear day, you can see mt diablo, the eastbay, san mo bridge and the farallons. didnt i say nice views?
author: Euge L.

description:
One word for my first time visit the other day - creepy!

Climbing through the darkened trees, wind and fog whipping around, hair flying in all directions while fat drops of water drip from above in my eyes and on my glasses. I get a rock in my shoe and my husband teases me with stories of a witch buried under the cross at the top, and how she chooses her victims by placing pebbles in their shoes. Suddenly, looming out of the mist is that monstrous cross, it's hard white edges so surreal and out of place amidst the trees. I think I actually shivered when I saw it towering over me in the swirling fog.

Reading about the plight of the Armenians was touching and it was interesting to know the history of that large yet hidden monument.  But now I need to find out more about that whole witch thing...
author: GIR ..

description:
1/17/09 - Today's hike with 50-60 attendees from SF City Guides and Yelp turned out a successful attendance.  The weather was warm and sunny.  Jacqueline Proctor led our tour with the history of this area and shared her binder full of pictures and stories.  We were led through an easy path up to the summit where the cross stands and vantage points look out over the city.  
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Bet you didn't know that Mt. Davidson is the highest peak in San Francisco. It's sort of my back yard. It's a quiet little get away from city bustle. It's a short steep hike if you enter from the southeast side of the mountain where I take my dog here for walks. There was a hidden Tarzan like swing here at one time. I'm not sure if it is still there. I once tried to exit the mountain through the northwest side but lost the trail and got scratched badly by the brush. I was headed in the right direction but ran into deep brush as I descend off trail on the mountain. The view of the cross from the base is awesome! I actually hiked up here one Easter morning with hundreds of other people before sunrise for its nondenominational service.  If you have the time, this is a nice San Francisco off the beaten path to explore.
author: Nanette L.

description: At nine hundred twenty-seven feet, the summit of Mt. Davidson is the highest point in San Francisco. For years it has been crowned by a giant cross, which in a PC-era raised Constitutional concerns that led to the sale of the cross and the land immediately around it to the Council of Armenian-American Organizations of Northern California in 1997. The park - which is bounded by Juanita, Dalewood, and Myra Ways and Molimo Drive - remains open to the public and provides a pleasant hike with spectacular views in practically every direction, and an appropriate setting for non-denominational sunrise services on Easter Sunday morning.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
Lived in SF my whole life and just never took the time to explore. Last weekend, we decided to take a hike up to the 'big cross' we always see from the road. It's a beautiful and peaceful (and easy) walk up to the top. Gorgeous views of the city. 

The only bad thing that kind of took away from it all was the fenced off areas along the trail and part of the peak. I guess if we came up from the other side, it would have been easier to get to, but we maneuvered our way between the bushes and the chain link fence and made it to the cross. 

It's such a humbling experience to see that cross looming over you, and it's so very peaceful up there. It was just us and two bikers who had stopped to have lunch there. So serene, with only the sound of the dry leaves crunching under my feet cutting through the quiet.
author: Denise M.

description: Here's my review, graphically: http://sfbay.ca/2011/11/16/mount-davidson-park/
author: Mari N.

description:
My family loves to walk to Mt. Davidson.  From our house, we can hike through the winding street terrain.  The views from the top are amazing. If you're a follower of Jesus - that cross is inspiring.  Beautiful public park. Tough to climb after a rain, so best to do when it's dry.  

The cross is usually lit up on the night before Easter.  

I once took my son and 4 of his 5th grade friends for a hike and game of ditch 'em.  Man that was fun - lots of running, hiking and room for them to be boys. 

This is most definitely one of the hidden gems of San Francisco.  I like to take visitors here.  Interesting, many residents of SF have never been here.  I often take people for their first time.
author: David L.

description:
This park works on early Easter Sunday morning. I saw Louis Manapuak..(think that's how he spells his name) play trumpet at 5 am and that is difficult when your lips are next to some cold metal. Hey, I am not Christian, but I don't mind the idea of a hill with a cross on it because if you think about it many of the things you see in this city have crosses on it are are just plain cross with the world..so to speak.

I love the smell of the eucalyptus leaves on the trails and 
 it was featured in a dirty Harry movie too...scarry at night, but check it out 5 am on Easter Sunday...pretty cool.
author: miriam b.

description:
So I'm not crazy about the gigantic cross at the top of the hill, but Mount Davidson offers amazing views of the Bay area and makes you feel like you've been transported out the city. We were lucky and headed up there on a very sunny day, but I imagine it gets pretty cold on your average foggy, windy SF kind of day. 

It's a great place for a quick escape from city life. Mount Davidson is in a neighborhood called "Sherwood Forest" that is very close to West Portal, Twin Peaks, and Diamond Heights. I think there are all sorts of micro-neighborhoods up there that I never knew about. You will be pleasantly surprised as you walk up the easy paths to the top of the hill...you really are in a forest and it's beautiful. 

We could see Bernal Hill from the top and it looked like an ant hill. This place was impressive, dog friendly, and very peaceful.
author: Abby W.

description:
The cross is nice, the views are totally different than any other hill, but the jungly interior is definitely something else. Find the great glenn just North of the cross and have a picnic with the fairies and leprechauns that obviously live there.

Access across from 27 Dalewood Way.
author: Geronimo G.

description: Great spot to take a little hike to. There's a couple different routes to take and it's amazing to see just how big the cross is once you get up close. And some great views once you get up there. It's too bad they don't illuminate the cross at night anymore
author: Maria M.

description:
Who knew there were such great views? The peak of the mountain is obscured by Eucalyptus trees, but the north and east sides of the mountain are not. You can see Bernal Heights, downtown, the bay, Mount Sutro and more. There's a real diversity of plants and wildflowers, and wonderful little trails with stone steps.

The cross on top seemed strangely out-of-proportion to me, the way the arms are just a little too short, and the concrete pad it sits on is reminiscent of the Nike missle sites that dot the city. Tastes change over time, I guess; at one time, the cross was considered one of the most important landmarks of the city.

Oh, and the best part is, you don't really have to street-hike (or drive, beh) to get to the park; just take the 36-Teresita from Forest Hill station. It only leaves about every half hour, so check this link on NextMuni before you leave: http://www.nextmuni.com/predictor/prediction.shtml?a=sf-muni&r=36&d=36_IB1&s=5453&ts=5452.
author: Dave M.

description:
Why is this park awesome?  any different from the rest of the SF parks?
Well, its the highest  (move over, twin peaks) and it also feels like a magical almost-jungle-like forest.  You only get that here and in GG Park (perhaps you've heard of that one).

I also really love the view from the top on the east side.  Beautiful.  I also love that you have to walk up to it ... no cheating by driving.  Sorry tourist buses.

Oh, and there's this giant cross thing and its like private cuz chuch and state is like oil and water yada-yada-blah.
author: chad n.

description:
Twin Peaks is the tourist attraction.

Mount Davidson is the diamond in the rough.
author: Thea G.

description:
I can walk here from my new house, which is awesome.  Don't get me wrong, I usually drive - because I'm lazy - but I could walk, in theory.  My favorite time at Mt. Davidson is on a foggy morning, when the rest of San Francisco disappears into the mist, and it feels like you're the only sentient being around for miles as you meander through the trails, looking for somewhere to pee.  

PS: Even though the main entrance is currently closed due to construction work, don't be dissuaded - you can still walk into the park through one of the side entrances.
author: Jess T.

description:
We watched the fireworks from 4th of july here and it was a really unique experience.. You can see downtown (not embarcadero really though) across the bay to oakland and down the peninsula to... somehwere down south ha ha.  For fouth of july, you 1. definitely need to bring flashlights and 2. be aware that the later it gets, depending on the wind, the harder it will be to see anything because all the smoke from the fireworks on the beach will definitely affect visibility.

Otherwise, this is a really unique place to hike.  From the top, you have an awesome view of the city. And the weird armenian cross at the top is interesting to see..  The hiking itself is pretty easy (if you're in reasonable shape), and (surprisingly) full of plantlife.  I like when it's sort of damp out (from rain or fog) and you get the earthy eucalyptus smell.

I would give it 5 stars but I prefer larger parks and longer hikes.  It's definitely worthwhile to check out though.
author: soy y.

description:
Great Spot.  Truly breathtaking on a clear day.  The hiking is steep at times, but a great spot.

There has been some construction lately, so hopefully they will be putting some little things in to make this a 5 star spot.  Some areas have a lot of broken glass and there could be a few more benches to enjoy the great views.

Even with that, everyone who calls themselves a San Franciscan should see this spot.
author: Keith J.

description:
Great place from which to admire the city away from the tourists and the tour buses of Twin Peaks.  Awesome views of the peninsula particularly at sunset, but I wouldn't advise hanging out alone on Mt. Dave at that time of night.

Trail route up the fire road & loop back to bus stop:
http://www.trailspotting.com/2008/10/mt-davidson-san-francisco.html
author: Stuart G.

description: I love love loveeeeee Mt. Davidson!  I may be a little biased as I live around the corner from the entrance to the park, but it is one of the nicest places in the city to get out and go for a hike.  My favorite spot is on the outlook point facing Twin Peaks and Sutro Tower under the big dead tree.  When my husband and I moved to the area in 2008, we would take daily walks up the mountain with our pug.  We have since acquired more pugs and still enjoy taking walks.  If you go on a foggy day, wear some hiking boots or rubber boots because it gets pretty muddy up there.
author: Rachael J.

description:
easily one of my favorite places in the city. since its the highest point in the city you can always guarantee fantastic views and lots of wind. for the people complaining about the absence of a 360 view you gotta remember how the place would be SO MUCH MORE COLD than it already is up there. besides, the views of downtown are spectacular enough to keep me going back up there from time to time. its a bit of a trek up the trail to get to the top. there are a few routes you can take and all of them are fun and help you feel like you're not in the city (which is always nice). 

during the day you can always expect the tourists and dog walkers to be all over the place. at night you can expect the drunken high schoolers and in the early morning i even hear that some religious groups gather for a sunrise mass. but no matter when you go you can expect lots of wind and AMAZING views of the city. a must see for everyone in my opinion. probably the best time to go would be on one of those unusually hot san francisco days. 

i also always dug that this was where dirty harry finally met up with scorpio in the original movie.
author: Andrew D.

description: Amazing views of San Francisco from this little known park at the top of SF's highest hill. Not quite as spectacular (or easy to get to) as Twin Peaks, and not as cool as Bernal Hill, Mt. Davidson is still a nice little hike that's perfect on a hot clear day. I love the windswept Eucalyptus trees on the west face - smells great up there.
author: Bart C.

description: Saturday was a weird day. It was sunny clear and warm in the outer sunset all day and freezing and windy everywhere else! We hiked from the outlands to Mt. Davidson and up through the Eucalpytus grove. I nearly fell off the path a couple times as I was watching for breaking branches. Once to the top, it was weird to see fog everywhere but the Sunset. Usually it is the opposite although I have to say in the 8 years I have lived here, the Sunset is getting to be more sunny than not. You can choose small or wide trails and they all take you up to the cross. We worked our way back down to Miraloma and then Glen Park and then the Mission where we froze our asses off at El Rio but watched some amazing afternoon bands.
author: Amy E.

description: Could be the best bang for the buck in the city.  I'm not talking about money either -- it's free.  But, if you walk up the trail, it will take you about 10 minutes to get to the best views in the city.  You just can't beat that.  Lots of small trails that circumnavigate it are great too.
author: Tim G.

description: nice view...big white cross....novice trails...but trying to remember where i parked the car....2 hour trek through the residential neighborhood and streets...leave breadcrumbs behind you as you start walking away from your car.....
author: Hen A.

description:
i think it is a good place for people walk around in city. 
nice view...very short route. quiet and relax. i will go back for sure.
author: B B.

description: Look up at the giant cross and watch the hummingbirds fly all around the top of it.  The view isn't as expansive as Twin Peaks, but it's still a great spot.
author: J J.

description: I don't even know which neighborhood is this. Diamond Heights?? OK, well me and a couple of friends came here for a short simple hike after a delicious brunch at Mama's (more yelping on that later). The GF suggested this place because it is close, easy, and apparently used to be one of her childhood school hikes from elementary school. That was the last time she been there so she has no recollection of how it was, but if you can do it in elementary school, it cant be that hard.  Windy residential drive up there lays a small park out of nowhere. The initial hill looks challenging especially after having a food baby from brunch, how thats pretty much. Needless to say, we got to the top in 10 min. The hike was not difficult but the view was actually pretty spectacular, a panoramic  view of SF. After a couple of pictures, we walked through other trails and found a huge 10 story Cross in the middle of the park.
author: Peter L.

description:
i'm giving this park 4 stars and not 5 because of how short the hike to the top is.  nonetheless, it was a good hike and the top definitely has a rewarding view.  it opens up to a view of the city and the distinct rows of SF houses.  

overall, i would do this hike again just to go to the top and look at the city. we went on a nice sunny, but still cool day and it was great.
author: Jodi P.

description: Decided to forgo my usual spot at Dolores Park today to try a new park, and with the nice weather, took the opportunity to check out Mt. Davidson. Awesome. The views are stunning and inspiring, and the hike up not too bad. Definitely check out this hidden treasure.
author: Jason B.

description: Great views, and the giant cross is impressive. Plus, you can reenact the scne where Dirty Harry shoots Scorpio. Tons of criss-crossing trails here - I didn't explore them all.
author: Philip T.

description: I have begun a quest to find baby and dog friendly ways to get exercise in SF and someone suggested Mt. Davidson, so I packed up my boy and my dog and tried it out. I have lived in the city for 10 years and had never heard of this place so it was fun to branch out. All in all, it was a pleasant experience - a gorgeous day with wild flowers. It is a fine place to visit, my only complaint is that I wanted a good work out and the trails aren't that long or that steep. But for a leisurly stroll I would recommend, although I live in Bernal Heights and thing that Bernal Hill is nicer.
author: Lynn G.

description: This has some of the best views in the city. It's also a great place to watch fireworks on the 4th as long as it's not foggy! Lots of people bring their dogs here as well so feel good in knowing man's best friend is welcome.
author: Michael G.

description: crazy about the giant cross on the mountain.  im glad it was bought privately and left there.  love it.
author: Doug ..
